passage.infon: cell migration cell polarity Hippo kinase RhoG Cell Adhesion, Polarity & Cytoskeleton Development & Differentiation
passage.text: Hippo kinases maintain polarity during directional cell migration in Caenorhabditis elegans
Abstract

Precise positioning of cells is crucial for metazoan development. Despite immense progress in the elucidation of the attractive cues of cell migration, the repulsive mechanisms that prevent the formation of secondary leading edges remain less investigated. Here, we demonstrate that Caenorhabditis elegans Hippo kinases promote cell migration along the anterior–posterior body axis via the inhibition of dorsal–ventral (DV) migration. Ectopic DV polarization was also demonstrated in gain‐of‐function mutant animals for C. elegans RhoG MIG‐2. We identified serine 139 of MIG‐2 as a novel conserved Hippo kinase phosphorylation site and demonstrated that purified Hippo kinases directly phosphorylate MIG‐2S139. Live imaging analysis of genome‐edited animals indicates that MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation impedes actin assembly in migrating cells. Intriguingly, Hippo kinases are excluded from the leading edge in wild‐type cells, while MIG‐2 loss induces uniform distribution of Hippo kinases. We provide evidence that Hippo kinases inhibit RhoG activity locally and are in turn restricted to the cell body by RhoG‐mediated polarization. Therefore, we propose that the Hippo–RhoG feedback regulation maintains cell polarity during directional cell motility.
Introduction

Directional cell migration plays essential roles in organism development and immune responses, as well as cancer invasion and metastasis (Kassis et al, 2001; Petrie et al, 2009; Clark & Vignjevic, 2015). For example, neuronal migrations contribute to the overall morphology and connectivity of nervous systems, and disruptions in the location of cortical neurons lead to the malformation of cortical development and neuropsychiatric diseases, including schizophrenia and autism (Singh et al, 2010; Wegiel et al, 2010; Blockus & Chedotal, 2014). In response to chemical gradients, migrating cells stimulate the local activity of the Rac family GTPases that drive actin polymerization and membrane protrusion in the leading edge (Etienne‐Manneville & Hall, 2002; Rossman et al, 2005; Ridley, 2015). Rac GTPases are evenly distributed along the plasma membrane, and uniform actin assembly abolishes cell motility; thus, an important challenge in a migrating cell is how to prevent the formation of secondary fronts by confining Rac activity within the lamellipodium (Fukata et al, 2003; Ridley, 2015).

The cycled activity of Rac GTPases between the GTP‐bound active conformation and GDP‐bound inactive conformation is regulated by guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs), GTPase‐activating factors (GAPs), and guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors (GDIs) (Ridley, 2015; Hodge & Ridley, 2016). Rac GTPase activity is also modulated by posttranslational modifications, including prenylation, phosphorylation, sumoylation, and ubiquitylation (Hodge & Ridley, 2016). Polarity establishment in migrating cells is thought to occur via positive feedback, which amplifies tiny and transient fluctuations into a substantial and persistent asymmetry in protein distribution (Houk et al, 2012; Graziano & Weiner, 2014). To maintain cell polarity, the plasma membrane tension has recently been demonstrated to comprise an important source that constrains the spread of the leading edge and prevents the formation of additional fronts (Houk et al, 2012; Graziano & Weiner, 2014). Alternatively, the leading edge may generate long‐range diffusive inhibitors or sequester polarity components to block the formation of additional leading edges. However, many underlying diffusive inhibitors or polarity components have not been identified, and even for the established components, the connection between these factors and Rac activity is unexplored.

Caenorhabditis elegans Q neuroblasts provide a valuable model system to investigate cell polarity during directional cell migration (Ou & Vale, 2009; Chai et al, 2012). In the L1 larvae, the Q neuroblasts, QR on the right side of the animal and QL on the left, move to the stereotypic positions along the anterior–posterior body axis but in different directions; the QR and descendants (abbreviated as QR.x) migrate anteriorly, and the QL and descendants (QL.x) migrate posteriorly (Sulston & Horvitz, 1977; Ou & Vale, 2009) (Fig 1A). The MIG‐13/LRP12 signaling pathway attracts QR.x to move toward the anterior (Sym et al, 1999; Wang et al, 2013), whereas the Wnt/beta‐catenin signaling cascade instructs the posterior migration of QL.x (Whangbo & Kenyon, 1999; Mentink et al, 2014). Q cells also have the capacity to move toward the dorsal–ventral axis as no neighboring tissues block migration on this axis (Ou & Vale, 2009; Mentink et al, 2014); however, they persistently move along the AP axis without an apparent DV deviation (Fig 1A and Movie EV1), and the repulsive mechanism of this process is largely unknown.
Hippo kinases promote AP migration via prevention of DV polarization

Model of Q‐cell position and migration direction in Caenorhabditis elegans L1 larvae. Green arrow indicates that Q cells migrate along the AP body axis, whereas the dotted red arrows indicate that Q cells are potent to move toward the DV direction. A, anterior; P, posterior; D, dorsal; V, ventral. Q, QL and QR indicate the Q neuroblast; AQR, PQR, SDQR, SDQL, AVM and PVM are the terminally differentiated neurons of Q neuroblast.

Schematics of the cst‐1 and cst‐2 gene models and DNA sequences of the cst‐1 and/or cst‐2 mutants that were generated via CRISPR–Cas9. Purple bar, serine/threonine kinase domain; blue bar, SARAH (Salvador–Rassf–Hippo homolog) domain. Arrow, sgRNA target site; green, target sequence; red, PAM sequence; blue, inserted nucleotide; dashed lines, deleted nucleotides.

Quantification of AQR position in adult WT and cst‐1 and/or cst‐2 mutant animals. The full length between the URXs and the end of the nematode tail is divided into 10 blocks, and the percent of AQR that stopped within each block is indicated. ***P < 0.001 by Fisher's exact test. N = 50–109.
Quantification scheme of the angle (α) between the longitudinal axis of a migrating cell and the AP body axis.

Fluorescence time‐lapse images of F‐actin, plasma membrane, and histones during AQR/QR.ap migration in WT (E) or cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant (F) animals. Merged images, left; inverted fluorescence images of F‐actin, right; white arrows, migration direction; asterisks, nucleus; double‐headed arrows, migration distance. F‐actin is labeled with GFP tagged with the actin‐binding domain of Moesin (GFP::Moesin ABD), and the plasma membrane and histones are labeled with mCherry tagged with a myristoylation signal or a histone, respectively. The dotted lines indicate the cell periphery. Time is presented in minutes. Scale bars, 5 μm.

Quantification of the QR.ap migration angle (G and H), distance (I), and speed (J). Each line in (G and I) represents the measurement from one time‐lapse movie. Error bars indicate SD. N = 10–17. Statistical significance is based on Student's t‐tests, **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001.

Here, we demonstrated that C. elegans Hippo kinases inhibit the activity of the Rac GTPase MIG‐2 in actin assembly by directly phosphorylating MIG‐2 at a novel and conserved site, serine 139. We demonstrated that Hippo kinases are sequestered in the cell body in WT migrating cells, and the exclusion of Hippo kinases from the leading edge requires Rac activity. Our results suggest that Hippo kinases and MIG‐2 function in a negative feedback loop to safeguard the directionality of cell migration by blocking the formation of secondary leading edges.
Results
Caenorhabditis elegans Hippo kinase homologs promote Q‐cell migration

The canonical Hippo signaling pathway consists of Hippo kinases (MST1/2) and Warts (Wts/LAST1/2), the regulatory protein Salvador (Sav/SAV1) and Mob (Mats/MOB1), a transcriptional coactivator Yorkie (Yki/YAP/TAZ), and a transcriptional factor Scalloped (Sd/TEAD/TEF5) (Pan, 2010; Gaspar & Tapon, 2014; Yu et al, 2015; Sun & Irvine, 2016) (Fig EV1A and B). Our previous study demonstrated that the C. elegans Scalloped/TEAD/TEF5 homolog EGL‐44 regulates cell cycle exit during Q‐neuroblast development (Feng et al, 2013). To further investigate the function of other Hippo signaling components in C. elegans, we used CRISPR–Cas9‐based genome editing techniques to generate mutations or conditional mutations of these genes (Figs 1B and EV1C and D). We demonstrated that the C. elegans harboring mutations in the Hippo kinase cst‐1 and cst‐2 or conditional mutations in sav‐1 (Sav) and mob‐1 (Mats) were defective in AQR and PQR migration in adult animals (Figs 1C, EV1D, and EV2A and B). The Hippo signaling cascade has been implicated in numerous developmental events, such as organ size and cell proliferation (Harvey & Tapon, 2007; Pan, 2010; Yu et al, 2015); however, a direct role for Hippo components in cell migration regulation has not been previously established in metazoans.
Screening of Caenorhabditis elegans homologs of the Hippo signaling components for Q‐cell development and Q‐cell migration phenotype in sav‐1 and mob‐1 conditional mutant animals

Components of the Hippo signaling pathway in Drosophila (A) and their homologs in Drosophila, mammals, and C. elegans (B). Caenorhabditis elegans mutant alleles of the Hippo signaling components are listed on the right. Red, the mutants generated by this study.
Gene models of sav‐1, wts‐1, and mob‐1. Exons are in boxes, and different colors denote different domains; arrows indicate sgRNA sequences, and PAM domains are indicated in red.
Quantifications of the AQR or PQR position in sav‐1‐sg, wts‐1‐sg, mob‐1‐sg, and yap‐1 mutant animals with representative gels of deletion mutations generated by the somatic CRISPR–Cas9 strategy.

Quantification of the QR.ap (E and G) or QL.ap (I and K) migration angle, distance (F and J), and speed (H and L). Each line in (E, F, I, and J) represents the measurement from one time‐lapse movie of QR.ap or QL.ap migration. Error bars indicate SD. N = 11–13. *P < 0.05; ***P < 0.001 by Student's t‐tests.
Source data are available online for this figure.
Q‐cell migration phenotype in Hippo kinase mutant animals
Quantification of PQR position in WT and cst‐1 and/or cst‐2 mutants. N = 50–109. *P < 0.05 by Fisher's exact test.
Representative images of AQR in WT and cst‐1 and cst‐2 single‐ or double‐mutant animals at the L4 larval stage. Bars indicate the distance of AQR to URXs. Scale bar, 50 μm.

Quantification scheme of AQR (C) or PQR (D) positions in relation to M4 neurites (AQR) or the anus (PQR) in WT and mutants at the late L1 larval stage. We define the lengths between the M4 nucleus to the AQR nucleus as a and the M4 nucleus to the turning of its neuritis as b. The a/b values indicate the relative position of AQR. We used the Caenorhabditis elegans anus as a reference to define the relative position of PQR. The dotted blue line indicates the extension of the anus. The brown lines with the numbers indicate the different regions of PQR.

Quantification of AQR (E) and PQR (F) positions in WT, cst‐1;cst‐2, or cst‐1;cst‐2 rescue mutants at the late L1 stage. Error bars indicate SD. N = 42–63. *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001 by Student's t‐tests.

Fluorescence time‐lapse images of F‐actin, plasma membrane, and histones during QL.ap migration in WT (G) or cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant (H) animals. Merged images, left; inverted fluorescence images of the actin cytoskeleton, right; white arrows, migration direction; asterisks, nucleus; double‐headed arrows, migration distance. F‐actin is labeled with GFP tagged with the actin‐binding domain of Moesin (GFP::Moesin ABD), and the plasma membrane and histones are labeled with mCherry tagged with a myristoylation signal or a histone, respectively. The dotted lines indicate the cell periphery. Time is presented in minutes. Scale bars, 5 μm.

Quantification of the QL.ap migration angle in relation to the AP body axis (I and K), QL.ap migration distance (J), and speed (L). Each line in (I and J) represents the measurement from one time‐lapse movie of QL.ap migration. Error bars indicate SD. N = 11–24. **P < 0.01; ***P < 0.001 by Student's t‐tests.

By examining the final position of Q‐cell descendants in the mutant animals at the adult stage, we demonstrated that only 1.3–26.0% of AQR in the putative null cst‐1 or cst‐2 single or cst‐1;cst‐2 double mutants arrived at their destination as the WT cells (Figs 1C and EV2B; N = 50–109 for each genotype). We confirmed the Q‐cell migration defects in cst‐1;cst‐2 double mutants by examining the positions of AQR and PQR in late L1 larvae (Fig EV2C–F and Appendix Fig S1). CST‐1 and CST‐2 share an identical catalytic serine/threonine kinase domain (100% sequence identity) at their N‐termini, and CST‐1 has an extra SARAH domain (Salvador–Rassf–Hippo homolog domain) that may mediate homologous and heterologous dimerization (Thompson & Sahai, 2015). In cst‐1 and cst‐2 single or double mutants, the Q‐cell migration is reduced to levels that are indistinguishable from each of the multiple alleles (Fig 1C). Importantly, we introduced GFP‐tagged cst‐1 or cst‐2 or both genes into the double‐mutant animals using a Q‐cell‐specific promoter Pegl‐17 and demonstrated that the cell migration phenotype was fully rescued in the presence of both cst‐1 and cst‐2 in contrast to the single gene (Fig EV2E and F). These findings indicated that CST‐1/2 are both required for cell migration and suggested that Hippo kinases act autonomously in migrating cells. Furthermore, the live imaging inspection of Q‐cell asymmetric division and apoptosis in the double mutants indicated that Q cells undergo normal division and programmed cell death in larvae (N > 10; Appendix Fig S2A and B); moreover, no ectopic gain or loss of Q‐cell progenies was identified in these adult mutant animals (N > 50; Appendix Fig S2C), which demonstrates a specific cell migration defect rather than an indirect consequence of Q‐cell proliferation or apoptosis.
CST‐1/2 maintain cell polarity in migrating Q cells

To address the cellular mechanism of CST‐1/2 in cell migration, we examined QR.ap and QL.ap (Q.ap) cell morphology and actin cytoskeleton in migrating cells of L1 larvae. The plasma membrane and nuclei of Q cells were labeled using mCherry carrying a myristoylation signal and an mCherry‐tagged histone, respectively, and the actin cytoskeleton was marked using GFP tagged with the actin‐binding domain of Moesin (GFP::Moesin ABD). In the WT animals, QR.ap/AQR persistently extends the F‐actin‐enriched lamellipodium toward the anterior and migrates to the head of the animal (Fig 1E and Movie EV1). In the cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant animals, QR.ap polarizes toward both the AP and DV body axes (Fig 1F and Movie EV2). To quantify the migration direction, we measured the angle between the Q‐cell longitudinal axis and the C. elegans AP body axis (schematic in Fig 1D). The WT Q.ap only changed their angles within 20° during a 40‐min time‐lapse recording, whereas the cst‐1;cst‐2‐double‐deficient Q.ap dramatically altered the migration direction, thereby varying the angles from 0° to ± 90° (Figs 1G and H, and EV2G–L). As a result, Q.ap failed to continuously translocate soma toward the anterior, which reduced the QR.ap or QL.ap migration speed from 25.3 to 17.1 μm/h or from 17.9 to 10.6 μm/h, respectively (Figs 1I and J, and EV2L). These findings indicate that Hippo kinases regulate cell polarity via the prevention of ectopic DV polarization in migrating cells.

We subsequently aimed to understand the downstream substrates of CST‐1/2 in cell migration. Mutations of sav‐1/Sav and mob‐1/Mats in contrast to wts‐1/Warts or yap‐1/Yki reduced A/PQR migration (Fig EV1D). The migration speed and distance decreased in the sav‐1‐ or mob‐1‐deficient Q.ap; however, our time‐lapse recording did not indicate an apparent abnormality in cell polarity (Fig EV1E–L, Movies EV3 and EV4, and Appendix Fig S3A and B). These findings indicate that SAV‐1 and MOB‐1 regulate Q‐cell migration in polarity‐independent mechanisms and suggest that Hippo kinases promote cell migration through the previously uncharacterized downstream components. Considering that the Rac GTPase is a master regulator of actin organization and polarity establishment during cell migration (Fukata et al, 2003; Pollard & Cooper, 2009; Ridley, 2015), we performed a fluorescence time‐lapse analysis of the actin cytoskeleton, migration angle, and speed of migrating cells in the mutants defective in MIG‐2, which encodes a C. elegans Rac GTPase and is also considered to be the mammalian RhoG homolog (Zipkin et al, 1997; Ou & Vale, 2009). The mig‐2(mu28) null mutation has previously been demonstrated to disrupt the actin assembly in the leading edge (Wang et al, 2013); interestingly, the gain‐of‐function mutation in mig‐2(rh17) caused the migrating Q.ap cells to orientate their lamellipodia toward the DV body axis (Ou & Vale, 2009) (Figs 2A and B, and EV3A and B, and Movie EV5). We demonstrated that the migration angles varied up to 135° in QR.ap or 180° in QL.ap along the AP axis, and the migration speeds were significantly reduced to 13.0 μm/h in QR.ap or 4.1 μm/h in QL.ap of the mig‐2(rh17) animals (Figs 1H and J, 2C, EV2K and L, and EV3A–C). The ectopic DV polarization and reduced cell migration in the constitutively active mig‐2(rh17) allele mimic the cell migration defects identified in the cst‐1;cst‐2 mutant animals. We noticed that Q‐cell migration phenotypes in mig‐2(rh17) were more severe than those in cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant animals (Figs 1H and J, and EV2K and L). Considering that the G16R mutation in mig‐2(rh17) allele blocks GTP hydrolysis and locks it to the constitutively active form (Zipkin et al, 1997), the phosphorylation of MIG‐2 by CST‐1/2 may modulate MIG‐2 activity in a subtler manner than the block of GTP hydrolysis.
Ectopic DV polarization in mig‐2 gain‐of‐function mutants and the phosphorylation of MIG‐2S139 by Hippo kinases

The dotted lines indicate the cell periphery. Time is presented in minutes. Scale bar, 5 μm.

In vitro phosphorylation assay of CST‐1/2 to MIG‐2. Bacterially expressed His‐tagged MIG‐2 or His‐tagged MIG‐2S139A was incubated with the GST‐tagged kinase domain of GST‐CST‐1/2 (1–318 aa). The kinase may use ATP‐γ‐S as a phosphodonor to thiophosphorylate its substrate; thus, the phosphorylation reaction was performed with ATP‐γ‐S, and anti‐thiophosphate ester antibody was used to detect substrate phosphorylation (Allen et al, 2005, 2007). The final reaction was probed via immunoblotting with antibodies as indicated. Thio, thiophosphate ester.

The accession version is as follows: C. elegans, CAB01691.1; Drosophila, CAC88352.1, AAA67041.1; human, CAB53579.5; rat, NP_599193.1; mouse, AAH51053.1; chicken, NP_990348.1, NP_001188381.1; zebrafish, AAV85902.1; Xenopus, NP_001089332.1.

Source data are available online for this figure.
CST‐1/2 phosphorylate MIG‐2S139

To investigate whether the phosphorylation of MIG‐2 by CST‐1/2 may represent a potential mechanism that prevents ectopic cell migration, we used affinity purification and mass spectrometry to identify the phosphorylation site(s) of MIG‐2 in C. elegans larvae. Using an anti‐GFP antibody, we purified GFP‐tagged MIG‐2 from the lysate of transgenic C. elegans larvae that expressed GFP::MIG‐2 fusion protein (Fig EV3D). An analysis of the phosphopeptides indicated that serine 139 of MIG‐2 was phosphorylated (Fig 2D). Our in vitro phosphorylation assay demonstrated that the purified CST‐1/2 kinase phosphorylates MIG‐2S139 in contrast to MIG‐2S139A (Fig 2E). The sequence alignment of MIG‐2 with other Rho family GTPases demonstrates that this site is uniquely conserved in Rac1 subfamily proteins in contrast to other Rho family GTPases across species (Figs 2F and EV3E). Interestingly, MIG‐2 and Rac1 proteins have been reported to regulate cell migration or neurite outgrowth (Zipkin et al, 1997; Ridley, 2015), which suggests that serine 139 phosphorylation may be responsible for a subtype of cellular activities, such as cell motility. Phosphorylation of Ras GTPases close to the C‐terminal CAAX motif has been demonstrated to alter the enzyme localization by influencing lipid modification (Lang et al, 1996; Hodge & Ridley, 2016), whereas phosphorylation within the GTPase domain may affect GTP‐GDP cycling and/or the association with Rho effectors (Kwon et al, 2000; Tong et al, 2013; Hodge & Ridley, 2016). By comparing MIG‐2 with human Rac1 whose structural information is available (Krauthammer et al, 2012), we demonstrated that MIG‐2S139/Rac1T135 locates between the last two α‐helixes (Fig 2G and H). MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation may affect the adjacent Pro140 conformation and thus vary the angle of the last α‐helix, which likely affects its interaction with other regulators or downstream effectors. The phosphorylation regulation of this region in Rho family GTPases has not been previously reported, and its functional significance is unknown.
MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation regulates actin assembly in migrating cells

We subsequently aimed to determine the physiological relevance of CST‐1/2‐mediated MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation for MIG‐2 function in C. elegans. We expressed the WT MIG‐2, the phosphor null mutant MIG‐2S139A, or the phosphomimetic mutant MIG‐2S139E in mig‐2(mu28)‐null Q cells. The WT MIG‐2 could rescue A/PQR migration phenotypes in the mig‐2(mu28) mutant animals; however, the MIG‐2S139A and MIG‐2S139E mutation failed to rescue AQR migration or only marginally rescued PQR migration, and MIG‐2S139E even enhanced AQR migration defects (Figs 3A and EV4A). Considering that MIG‐2 needs to be activated in the leading edge and inhibited in the posterior, the loss of MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation may perturb the local modulation of MIG‐2 activity, thereby causing defective cell migration. The enhanced migration defects of MIG‐2S139E transgene in mig‐2(mu28) mutant animals may be resulted from the dominant negative effect of overexpressed MIG‐2S139E protein. Overall, these data strongly suggest a key role for the phosphorylation of MIG‐2S139 in cell migration. We subsequently implemented the CRISPR–Cas9‐assisted homologous recombination technique to construct MIG‐2S139A and MIG‐2S139E knock‐in strains that are deficient in MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation (Dickinson et al, 2013). Consistent with our rescue results, 50.0 or 75.7% of AQR in the MIG‐2S139A or MIG‐2S139E mutant animals shortened their migration distance, and 11.7% of the PQR cells in the MIG‐2S139E animals also reduced migration (Figs 3B and EV4B). Furthermore, our fluorescence time‐lapse recording indicated that both the speed and the angle of Q.ap migration were substantially perturbed in the MIG‐2S139A and MIG‐2S139E mutant animals (Figs 3C–F and EV4C–F, and Movies EV6 and EV7). For example, ectopic DV polarization and variations in the migration angle from 0° to ± 90° or ± 135° were identified in the Q.ap cells of the MIG‐2S139A animals, which mirrors the Q.ap migration defects in cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant animals. Collectively, we provide in vivo evidence that the CST‐1/2‐dependent phosphorylation of MIG‐2S139 promotes cell migration via the prevention of ectopic polarization.
MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation regulates actin assembly during cell migration

Quantification of F‐actin enrichment ratio in WT and mig‐2 mutants. Error bars indicate SD. N = 35–45. ***P < 0.001 by Student's t‐test.

To further investigate the influence of serine 139 phosphorylation on the cellular activity of MIG‐2, we examined the morphology of migrating cells by measuring the area ratio of the cell body to the nucleus. A WT migrating cell extends large lamellipodia toward the migration direction with an average 3.0 ± 0.2 cell body to nucleus ratio, whereas the mig‐2(mu28) null mutation abolished the formation of lamellipodia and substantially reduced the ratio to 2.6 ± 0.1. Interestingly, the lack of MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation in the cst‐1;cst‐2 double‐mutant or MIG‐2S139A mutant animals increased the ratio to 3.6 ± 0.1 or 3.8 ± 0.2, respectively. However, the phosphomimetic MIG‐2S139E mutation reduced the ratio to 2.6 ± 0.1 (Figs 3G and H, and EV4G and H), which further supports the notion that MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation inhibits MIG‐2 activity in the formation of membrane protrusions. Furthermore, we investigated the distribution of the actin cytoskeleton in MIG‐2S139‐related mutants. By measuring the enrichment of GFP::Moesin ABD along the periphery of migrating cells, we demonstrated that 35% of the cell periphery was enriched with F‐actin, and most of the GFP fluorescence was identified in the leading edge of the WT cells. However, in the MIG‐2S139A mutant animals, 20% of the migrating Q.ap cells formed uniformly enriched F‐actin along the entire cell periphery; for the remaining 80% of the cells, the GFP fluorescence occupied up to 52% of the cell periphery. In contrast, the MIG‐2S139E mutation reduced the enrichment of GFP fluorescence to 29% on the cell periphery, and the GFP fluorescence intensity was dimmer compared with the WT cells (Figs 3I–L and EV4I–L). Importantly, we identified the formation of a spiky leading edge and the lack of a persistent anterior polarity during migration in the MIG‐2S139E cells (Fig EV3F and G). These phenotypes have also been identified in Arp2/3‐deficient cells, which are defective in actin polymerization at the leading edge, or anillin‐conditional mutants, in which F‐actin stability is perturbed in the lamellipodia (Wu et al, 2012; Tian et al, 2015; Swaney & Li, 2016). Taken together, our findings suggest that MIG‐2S139 phosphorylation by Hippo kinases inhibits the assembly of actin filaments in migrating cells.
Restriction of Hippo kinase in cell body requires MIG‐2

To address the dynamic localization of Hippo kinase during cell migration, we performed a live imaging analysis of the functional GFP‐tagged CST‐1 and CST‐1 reporters. After Q.a cell division, CST‐1/2 or the actin cytoskeleton was evenly distributed in the Q.ap. Because Q.ap quickly established cell polarity and started to migrate after cytokinesis, GFP::Moesin ABD was enriched at the leading edge within minutes, and the peak GFP fluorescence intensity was 0.1 ± 0.1 μm away from the cell periphery (Figs 4C and D, and EV5C). However, CST‐1 or CST‐2 was restricted within the cell body, and GFP‐tagged Hippo kinases localize in the region that is 1.2 ± 0.1 μm for CST‐1 and 1.9 ± 0.1 μm for CST‐2 away from the leading edge (Figs 4A and D, and EV5A and C, and Movies EV8 and EV9). In the mig‐2(mu28) null‐mutant animals, GFP‐tagged CST‐1 or CST‐2 was evenly distributed, and GFP fluorescence was detected 0.3 ± 0.1 μm and 0.5 ± 0.1 μm adjacent along the cell periphery, respectively (Figs 4B and D, and EV5B and C). During cell migration, GFP‐tagged CST‐1/2 were barely detectable in the lamellipodia, and the GFP fluorescence intensity ratios of the leading edge to the rear region were 0.37 ± 0.03 and 0.37 ± 0.04, respectively (Figs 4E and G, and EV5D and F). However, in the mig‐2‐deficient migrating Q.ap, the ratios were increased to 0.71 ± 0.08 and 0.77 ± 0.07 (Figs 4F and G, and EV5E and F), which indicates that CST‐1/2 were more evenly distributed in the absence of MIG‐2.

Discussion

Collectively, the results of this work support the existence of a negative feedback loop in which Hippo kinases that are restricted to the cell body by MIG‐2/RhoG inhibit RhoG activity out of the leading edge (Fig 4H). In this regulation, environmental cues initially activate the RhoG, which establishes the initial polarity toward the migration direction. Hippo kinases are subsequently excluded from lamellipodia and are restricted to the cell body, where they, in turn, phosphorylate MIG‐2 and inhibit its Rac activity, thereby preventing the formation of additional fronts. In a living organism, a migrating cell is capable of migrating to any of the body axes as long as the anatomy permits. Moreover, the small Rac GTPases evenly distribute on the plasma membrane and have the potential to be activated at any loci. Our model suggests that Rac activity may be constrained by the phosphorylation of Hippo kinases within the cell body, which maintains the persistent cell polarity toward the initially polarized direction by blocking ectopic polarization. Thus, the Hippo–RhoG negative feedback that acts together with the attractive mechanisms and other positive feedback contributes to the conversion of the random cell motility into directional cell migration in live metazoans.

Numerous previous studies regarding the role of kinases in cell migration have focused on their functions in receptor activation in the leading edge (Petrie et al, 2009; Wang et al, 2013; Ridley, 2015), whereas our discovery expands our fundamental understanding of how kinases use posttranslational modification to affect cell migration by negatively modulating the activity of the Rho family GTPase in the cell body. Our results also expand the functional repertoire of Hippo kinases by establishing a role of Hippo kinases in the direction of cell migration. This function appears to be independent of the other established Hippo components and may not involve transcriptional regulation, which is consistent with the notion that the canonical Hippo signaling pathway may not be assembled in nematodes; however, many of the conserved Hippo components are encoded by the C. elegans genome (Yang & Hata, 2013).

In the canonical Hippo signaling cascade, a series of phosphorylation reactions leads to the phosphorylation and retention of the transcriptional coactivator complex YAP/TAZ within the cytoplasm, which thereby blocks the transcription of target genes that are crucial for cell proliferation and death (Harvey & Tapon, 2007; Pan, 2010; Gaspar & Tapon, 2014; Yu et al, 2015). Recent studies have also demonstrated many other downstream substrates of Hippo kinases, which function independently of transcriptional regulation. For example, the phosphorylation of AKT and histone 2B by the mammalian Hippo kinase MST1/2 has been demonstrated to be essential for chromatin condensation during apoptosis (Cheung et al, 2003; Thompson & Sahai, 2015); moreover, phosphorylation of the autophagosome component LC3 by STK3/4 kinases is required to mediate the fusion of an autophagosome with a lysosome (Wilkinson et al, 2015). Our identification of MIG‐2/RhoG as a novel Hippo substrate indicates that Hippo kinases may directly function with plasma membrane proteins to regulate cellular activities. Of note, another Hippo signaling component, Wts, contributes to the proper migration of border cell clusters via the phosphorylation of an actin‐binding protein Ena in Drosophila (Lucas et al, 2013), which supports the notion that Hippo components have a transcription‐independent function in cell migration.

The interplay between Hippo signaling and Rho GTPase/the actin cytoskeleton has been demonstrated in various species (Gaspar & Tapon, 2014; Sun & Irvine, 2016). An increase in actin filaments correlates with an increased Yki activity in Drosophila or mammalian cells (Fernandez et al, 2011; Sansores‐Garcia et al, 2011). Rho GTPases and the actin cytoskeleton are essential for transducing the upstream inputs, such as the cell shape, cell density, cell attachment, ECM rigidity, and GPCR pathway, to the Hippo signaling cascade (Dupont et al, 2011; Sun & Irvine, 2016). Moreover, the inhibition of Rho GTPase activity or disruption of actin filaments caused the retention of Yorkie in the cytoplasm, which suggests that Rho GTPase activity and the actin architecture contribute to the activity of Hippo signaling (Aragona et al, 2013). In contrast, the Hippo components are also involved in actin assembly. The loss of Hippo and Warts homologs in S. pombe disrupted the organization of the actin cytoskeleton (Verde et al, 1995), and the mutations of the Drosophila Hippo or Wts caused the apical accumulation of actin filaments in imaginal disks (Fernandez et al, 2011), which suggested that F‐actin polarization may be the ancestral function of Hippo and Warts kinases. Different from these unidirectional regulations in the previously described scenarios, our results indicate that Hippo kinases and RhoG/MIG‐2 function in a negative feedback loop to promote directional cell migration. We speculate that Hippo–RhoG regulation must involve additional components. For example, it remains enigmatic how Hippo kinases are excluded from the leading edge by MIG‐2‐dependent polarization. Hippo kinases and RhoG are evolutionarily conserved molecules, and future studies will also need to investigate the generality of Hippo–RhoG feedback regulation across other species.
Materials and Methods
Caenorhabditis elegans strains, genetics, and DNA manipulations

Strains were cultured on nematode growth medium (NGM) plates seeded with E. coli OP50 at 20°C following standard protocols. Transgenic strains were generated with the microinjection of 1–50 ng/μl DNA with co‐injection markers into N2 or GOU174 germlines. Conditional knockout and knock‐in animals were generated using the CRISPR–Cas9 strategy and analyzed with PCR and Sanger sequencing (Dickinson et al, 2013; Shen et al, 2014). The sgRNA sequence, G(N)N19NGG (N = A, C, T, or G), was designed according to established criteria. The knock‐in template plasmids were constructed via amplification of the 1 to 1.5 kb upstream and downstream homology arms from the N2 genomic DNA and insertion into pPD95.77 via an In‐Fusion Advantage PCR Cloning Kit (Clontech). Tables EV1,EV2 andEV3 include the primers, plasmids, PCR products, and strains used in this study.
Molecular analysis

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was used to detect molecular lesions in conditional knockout animals. Worms were lysed with 10× PCR buffer, and the lysis was used as templates for the PCR of DNA fragments that contained CRISPR–Cas9 targets. Approximately 500 bp–1 kb DNA fragments upstream or downstream of the target sequences were amplified. The amplification progress contains two steps, including one short‐time elongation with 20 cycles, followed by the other long‐time elongation with 15 cycles. The PCR products were used for agarose gel electrophoresis and Sanger sequencing.
In vitro phosphorylation assay

A 100 ml mixture contained 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 10 mM DTT, and 1 mM ATP‐γ‐S with 2 μg of GST‐CST‐1/2 kinase domain or GST in a buffer. We added 5 μg His‐MIG‐2 or its mutant S139A as the substrate. After 30 min of incubation at room temperature, we added 5 μl of 50 mM p‐nitrobenzyl mesylate (catalog no. ab138910; Abcam) in the system and incubated at room temperature for an additional 2 h. The reaction was terminated via the addition of SDS sample buffer. Protein phosphorylation was detected by immunoblotting with anti‐thiophosphate ester antibody.
Live cell imaging

Live cell imaging was performed using a previously described protocol (Chai et al, 2012). L1 larval worms were anesthetized with 1 mg/ml levamisole and mounted on 3% agarose pads at 20°C. The immobilized larvae were subsequently imaged with an Axio Observer Z1 microscope (Carl Zeiss MicroImaging, Inc.) or an Olympus IX83 (Olympus, Inc.) equipped with a 100×, 1.45 N.A. objective, an EM CCD camera (Andor iXon+ DU‐897D‐C00‐#BV‐500), and the 488 nm and 568 nm lines of a Sapphire CW CDRH USB Laser System attached to the spinning disk confocal scan head (Yokogawa CSU‐X1 Spinning Disk Unit). Time‐lapse images were programmed to be captured via μManager (https://www.micro-manager.org/) with a 200‐ms exposure time and 1‐min intervals and processed with ImageJ software.
Quantifications of images

ImageJ software was used for the measurement and analysis of all images. The migrating cell angle indicated the angle between cell polarization (indicated by GFP::Moesin ABD accumulation) or migration and the worm anterior–posterior axis. The movies used for the migration angle, distance, and speed analysis consisted of a 40‐min migration with no apparent obstacles ahead; five arbitrary frames at 0, 10, 20, 30, and 40 min were analyzed, from which the mean value was calculated and grouped for statistical analysis. The cell body/nucleus area ratio and F‐actin accumulation were measured by circumscribing the fluorescence field along the cortex; the GFP::CST‐1 and GFP::CST‐2 polarized localizations were measured across the cell body. For all intensity measurements, the background was subtracted.
Mass spectrometry analysis

GFP::MIG‐2 immunoprecipitates were precipitated in cold acetone and dissolved in 100 mM Tris, pH 8.5, and 8 M urea. The proteins were subjected to reduction (5 mM TCEP), alkylation (10 mM iodoacetamide), and trypsin digestion (37°C overnight). For LC‐MS/MS analysis of the resulting peptides, we followed a previously described method (Zhao et al, 2015), except that SCX fractionation was omitted.

Raw data were extracted using RawXtract software. The MS/MS spectra were searched against the C. elegans protein database using Prolucid (Xu et al, 2015). The carbamidomethylation of cysteines was included as a fixed modification. The phosphorylations of serine, threonine, and tyrosine residues were included as variable modifications. The search results of the two technical replicates were independently filtered using DTASelect 2 (Tabb et al, 2002) by requiring a 1% FDR at the peptide level, a precursor mass accuracy ≤ 5 ppm, a Z‐score ≥ 4, and a minimum of one peptide for a protein ID. The FDR rates at the protein level were 1.26 and 1.02%. The spectra that displayed the phosphorylated peptide of MIG‐2 were annotated by pLable (Yang et al, 2012).

The WD scores of the MIG‐2 IP‐MS/MS data were calculated with other 32‐bit IP‐MS/MS matrix (W.‐J. Li, M. Zhu, Y.‐X. Li, M.‐Q. Dong, unpublished data) based on the WD‐score formulas from the CompPASS tutorial (Sowa et al, 2009).
Statistical analysis

Statistical analysis of A/PQR position was performed in R (R i386 3.3.1) with Fisher's exact test. Other quantitative data were analyzed in GraphPad Prism version 6 (GraphPad Prism Inc., San Diego, CA). Independent unpaired, two‐tailed Student's t‐tests were performed to compare the mean values between two groups. Statistical significances were designated as *P < 0.05; **P < 0.01; and ***P < 0.001.
Author contributions
GO, GF, ZZ, W‐JL, YC, and M‐QD conceived the experiments; GF, W‐JL, ZZ, QL, and YC performed the experiments; and GO and GF wrote the manuscript.
Conflict of interest
The authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
